ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Gained insight into how develop character. Professor Wallace is an excellent instructor and helpful in guiding students to have more naturalistic performances and focusing on affecting fellow actors on stage rather than feeling emotions on stage.
How to think and express feelings and achieves objectives in the plays and in life.
A new philosophy for the basis of acting: making the other person feel. Also, some new insights about how to prepare and what it means to perform. (Koosh was very informative in this last regard.)
Developing complex characters through the connection with others, specifics of action, and physical embodiment.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Professor Wallace is an excellent professor. He is incredibly kind, funny, knowledgeable. I learned so much as an actor and a director through his teaching. There were times when assignments and their due dates were a bit unclear. But on the whole, an excellent class.
The best acting class I've ever had.  The course was organized and taught with so much thoughtful planning and practical techniques from the professor's life-long experience.

My favorite thing about this course is that, in contrast to most advanced acting courses I've taken at Yale, it is not just a masterclass format, but involves full group work. I think this both allowed me to learn more things and fostered a better sense of community with the full group. We obviously were constantly running behind schedule, but I don't know that it would have been worth it to cut things short and push ahead, with possible exception of the presentations. I do think the directions for singing the other could have been a little clearer. (I didn't realize that we would be a cappella, and if I had I might have gone about things slightly differently.) Overall, though, this course is fantastic.

This course is a strong studio class. The teacher and environment makes you want to work harder and get out the ego of acting to truly love in the moment and deliver to an audience. I think the scheduling could be improved a little; because of the attention we bring to each scene, we werent able to finish sometimes, so some scenes & groups got more attention than others.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes absolutely. If you want to take a class where you can grow as a theater maker, take this course.

YES.  Highly recommend.  Whether you pursue a career in acting or not, this course can help you explore how to express feelings and connect with the audience on any stage with nothing but yourself.  The course helps explore how to use your own body, voice, and thoughts as instruments to achieve the objectives needed.

Absolutely. This was hands-down the best acting course I have taken at Yale. I learned a lot, but I also enjoyed the community and environment that was created from day one, and that is where this course stands out.
Absolutely. This is a great advanced acting course. Take it if you have time, though. It is tough to schedule outside rehearsals.
